DataElement.preferredName: Breast carcinoma Post Neoadjuvant Therapy Pathologic T Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Code to represent the post-neoadjuvant therapy pathologic T stage for a breast tumor as defined by the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Breast Tumor Post Neoadjuvant Therapy Pathology T Stage
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to post-neoadjuvant therapy pathologic T stage for a breast tumor, the extent of maiignant breast neoplasm  involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion) based on pathologic examination of a portion of the tumor using the TMN staging system following treatment designed to be used as a first step toward shrinking the cancer and in evaluating response to drugs and other agents. Induction therapy is followed by additional therapy to eliminate whatever cancer remains.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredName: Post Neoadjuvant Therapy Pathology T Stage
Property.preferredDefinition: Post; occuring after.:Treatment designed to be used as a first step toward shrinking the cancer and in evaluating response to drugs and other agents. Induction therapy is followed by additional therapy to eliminate whatever cancer remains.:A specialty concerned with the nature and cause of disease as expressed by changes in cellular or tissue structure and function caused by the disease process. (MSH98):One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
Therapy administered prior to the primary treatment for the purpose of making the primary treatment more effective.

The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Breast Tumor Post Neoadjuvant Pathologic T Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the post-neoadjuvant pathologic T (tumor) stage of a breast tumor, as defined by the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: EDEMA (INCLUDING PEAU D'ORANGE) OR ULCERATION OF THE SKIN OF THE BREAST OR SATELLITE SKIN NODULES CONFINED TO THE SAME BREAST

ValueMeaning.preferredName: EDEMA (INCLUDING PEAU D'ORANGE) OR ULCERATION OF THE SKIN OF THE BREAST OR SATELLITE SKIN NODULES CONFINED TO THE SAME BREAST
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: EDEMA (INCLUDING PEAU D'ORANGE) OR ULCERATION OF THE SKIN OF THE BREAST OR SATELLITE SKIN NODULES CONFINED TO THE SAME BREAST

An advanced, invasive breast adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of distinct changes in the overlying skin. These changes include diffuse erythema, edema, peau d'orange (skin of an orange) appearance, tenderness, induration, warmth, enlargement, and in some cases a palpable mass. The skin changes are the consequence of lymphatic obstruction from the underlying invasive breast adenocarcinoma. Microscopically, the dermal lymphatics show prominent infiltration by malignant cells. The invasive breast adenocarcinoma is usually of ductal, NOS type. There is not significant inflammatory cell infiltrate present, despite the name of this carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: An advanced, invasive breast adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of distinct changes in the overlying skin. These changes include diffuse erythema, edema, peau d'orange (skin of an orange) appearance, tenderness, induration, warmth, enlargement, and in some cases a palpable mass. The skin changes are the consequence of lymphatic obstruction from the underlying invasive breast adenocarcinoma. Microscopically, the dermal lymphatics show prominent infiltration by malignant cells. The invasive breast adenocarcinoma is usually of ductal, NOS type. There is not significant inflammatory cell infiltrate present, despite the name of this carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Breast Cancer pTis TNM Finding v6 and v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Breast cancer with a finding of carcinoma in situ. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Breast Cancer pTis TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Breast cancer with a finding of carcinoma in situ. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.
